div1.head: TO THE RIGHT HONOURABLE The Countess of SALISBURY.
div1.p: THE Attention with which you have protected the British Stage, claims the Gratitude of every Dramatic Writer: I therefore take the Liberty of dedicating this Comedy to your Ladyship, and humbly entreat your Forgiveness for not previously soliciting your Permission.

closer.salute: I have the Honour to be, MY LADY,
closer.signed: With the greatest Respect, Your Ladyship's most obedient And most humble Servant, LEONARD MAC NALLY.

div1.head: On seeing Miss YOUNGE in the Character of Lady FLIPPANT SAVAGE.
div1.l: THE two scenic Muses had long kept a distance,
And scorn'd of each other to borrow assistance;
THALIA was pert, and MELPOMENE proud,
And though of admirers they both had a croud;
Not two rival beauties on earth could be seen
More tortur'd with jealousy, envy and spleen:
Till JOVE, to whom all the celestials submit,
In matters of WEIGHT, or in matters of WIT,
Interpos'd his command, saying, henceforth agree,
United in friendship as Sisters should be;
And grant, as a pledge that your union's sincere,
Your mutual pow'rs to some favourite fair;
If one can be found amongst mortals below
Deserving the attributes you can bestow.
The Sisters obey'd; but unfix'd was their choice,
Till MINERVA appearing with soul-moving voice:
While in scales of suspense both their fancies were hung,
Appeal'd to their senses, and pointed to YOUNGE.
To YOUNGE, where the smile-stealing comic we find,
With the soft, the sublime, and the graceful combin'd.
To YOUNGE who can each diff'rent passion impart,
Who pleases the judgement, but conquers the heart,
And guided by NATURE, is followed by ART.

sp.l: IN Shakespeare's days we only play'd the fool,
And men of fashion gave—not took—the rule;
Then Lords were grave, and ladies graver still,
And only we, and clowns had wit at will;
His mind rejected former classic lore,
And drew from Nature's never-ending store.
But authors now—we often prove the fact,
Must fashion court, to teach us how to act.
Expose the follies which our statutes spare,
And unprotected Virtue make their care.
All nature now is custom;—custom, law;
And here we bring—not what we think,—but saw.
Tis hard to vary your dramatic mirth,
When every folly gives it likeness birth.
Which though, in life, your laugh they may command,
Will rather pall, than please, at second hand.
'Tis harder still to suit the general mind,
And all our audience in our int'rest bind.
Honest John Bull, vex'd with the cares of life,
With heavy taxes and a scolding wife,
Wishes some hours in hearing us to waste,
And galloping dreary Dun is quite his taste.—
Sir Foppling too, his brains with claret addle,
Pronounces Comedy to be a Twaddle!
His Lordship by the privilege of folly,
Is neither musical nor melancholy;
Thinks every honest bard a queer old Put,—
"Damme! there's nothing in a play like smut!
The politician's all-commanding pate,
Would have us dramatize th' affairs of state:
Make whigs and tories fight, here face to face,
And teach the patriots, Unity of Place.—
Some cry for sentiment, and some for wit,
And yet our claim to either won't admit.—
The Critic Bench!Looking into the Pit. for which there's no appeal,
Since for the town they judge, and act, and feel.
Did you but know what pangs an author shares,
How throbs his heart with anxious doubts and cares!
Let past indulgence your attention keep:
Though we be dull—Justice should never sleep.
And if to-night no merit we can claim,
The want of power, not will, deserves the blame!

div1.head: DRAMATIS PERSONAE.
div1.p: {inverted ⁂} Those lines which are within inverted commas, are omitted by the performers in the representation.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mus.
sp.p: AND do you really prefer London to Bath, Mrs. Grace?

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Why, I do; in London there's such a noise—such rattling of carts, waggons, coaches, chariots and vis-a-vis; then at night its so charming to see the flambeaux flying about from house to house, like blazing stars!—But what have you got there for my lady, Mrs. Muslin?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: A few cards of laces.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Foreign, I hope—we hate every thing English, and wear nothing but foreign manufactures. (Bell rings) My lady's bell.—Any new company come down?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mus.
sp.p: Have heard of none, except the wife and daughter of big Mr. Minikin, the great pinmaker from Threadneedle-street. (Bell rings.)

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Coming, my lady (goes to a door in the back scene.) It is only Mrs. Muslin, my lady.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: within. I'll be with her immediately.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Let me have a few words with you before you go—Sir Buzzard and my lady had such tifting yesterday, you never heard the like—They hate each other most affectionately, that is the truth of it—

div3.stage: Enter Lady FLIPPANT SAVAGE through a door in the back scene.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: So Muslin, (sits) Heigh ho! I'm all langour and lassitude!—Never knew Bath so dull—Scarce any person of fashion—Nobody one knows—This patch has a pretty effect—And you may go, Grace; and do you hear, Grace, let Miss Constance know I shall be ready to go out in half an hour.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Yes, my lady. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Muslin, take a chair;—this is certainly English rouge, a vulgar natural red.—Did you see my brute as you came in, Muslin?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mus.
sp.p: Saw two of them, dear pretty animals, in the hall, my lady; the little French dog was playing with the Spanish monkey.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Muslin, are you mad!—my dog and monkey brutes! sweet creatures! I was enquiring after the brute my husband.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mus.
sp.p: I ask your ladyship's pardon; I saw Sir Buzzard with Colonel Staff, and Mr. Cheaterly in the great parlour.—But I have something to mention to your ladyship—here are the laces— (opening the box) but it is not about the laces I want to speak—but—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: But what?—Heigh ho! hand me the Olympian dew—Muslin, I saw a charming fellow at the play last night, and he saw me—Lady Holden certainly pencils her eye-brows—But the charming fellow, he took up my whole attention from the performance—I flatter myself I engaged his—his eyes were never off me—was dressed in a new Parisian frock.—Hand me the volatile salts, Muslin.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mus.
sp.p: My lodger, I protest!—pick'd the pinion of a chicken at my humble table, last night, and never ceased talking of your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Hand me the rose water—he spoke of me, you say?—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mus.
sp.p: Heav'ns, said he, what an air!—what grace! then run on in praise of your ladyship's person and beauty; but when he heard your ladyship was married, poor youth, how piteously he sigh'd.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Good natured charitable soul!—but his name—who is he?—what is he? whence came he?—and who are his relations, Muslin?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mus.
sp.p: Cannot answer one of your ladyship's questions, except that his name is Welford; he came to my house yesterday, and talks of leaving Bath to-morrow morning.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Mr. Cheaterly requests permission to wait upon your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Shew him up. Exit. Grace. Come to demand his winnings;—lost two hundred last night, could think of no card but the knave of hearts I saw at the Theatre.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mus.
sp.p: The knave—the king of hearts your ladyship means; and let me tell you a trump—never saw finer eyes; then he has the leg of a soldier, and the hand of a lady—but is he to have the honor of—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Of what?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mus.
sp.p: He says he has something of a serious nature to communicate to your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Perhaps letters from some of my friends in Paris.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Saw a large bundle of letters on his table.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Then, Muslin, I leave his introduction to you—shall be at home all the morning.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Your ladyship's most obedient—I leave the laces. (going) Never saw a handsomer gentleman. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: What a giddy creature am I? but a body must kill time—then the fellow is so elegant, (rises) and Sir Buzzard so peevish!—the fatigue and apprehension which body and mind suffer after an unluckly run, are insupportable; my nerves are quite out of tune, but Muslin has in some degree elevated my spirits.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: I condole with your ladyship on your hard run last night; the aces conspired against you;—Renounce brag, the cunning of the game lies, not in—judgment of mind, but in command of muscles.

sp.speaker: La. Flip.
sp.p: To which I impute your uninterrupted series of good luck.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: I am unfit for brag;—the warmth of my heart, particularly in your ladyship's presence, (bows low.) keeps my features in continual rebellion,—but no person with a flexible countenance should touch brag, the impenetrable looks of lady Frigid Midnight, have established her an adept at the game.

sp.speaker: La. Flip.
sp.p: And her nimble fingers give her command of the cards; but she lost temper when I got the black knaves; it was when you stood on my right, and lord Lackacre on my left hand.—"I have got the black knaves," said I, "Lady Frigid"—"I see you have," said she, pointing to you and my lord,—then, as she puckered up her mouth in an affected smile, down fell a few flakes of paint, and her skin appeared under the fractures, like old brick work peeping through the new invented composition.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Her countenance was once tolerable, but a long run of ill luck, has stamp'd that irrisible discordancy, of hill and dale, which marks her visage, and prevents the smiles of fortune, joy, or good humour, from unbending her to a laugh, or the smallest semblage of the amiable. (Hums a tune.) There is a small matter between us, for which I have a very pressing occasion.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: (Aside.) I expected this! Ha! ha! ha! I cannot but laugh at your description of Lady Frigid.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: For heav'n's sake say no more of her;—but, let me have the money. (bows.)

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: The money! Psha! You must have patience.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Patience for a debt of honour!

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: I have bills to pay—my mercer, milliner, and mantua-maker, are to be with me to-morrow, and people of that class, you know, are rude and importunate.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: But suppose I point out a mode of discharging this debt of honour without diminishing your ladyship's purse—what say you?

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: If you have any thing to propose I can honourably receive, speak out.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Your ladyship is not usually slow of apprehension;—it is true, I have not made an open declaration of my passion.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: But my eyes, my looks, have spoke the workings of my soul.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: (Goes from him confused) This I never suspected. (Aside)

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: May I hope for your assistance towards my happiness; I have long loved, doated, and despaired.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Long loved and doated! I'm not surprized at that. (Aside.)

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Sir Buzzard knows of, and approves my passion.

sp.speaker: La. Flip.
sp.p: Sir Buzzard approves it!

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: He does,—and I cannot live—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Hold, Sir! (Aside.) I'm astonish'd.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: I cannot live without her.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Without her! without whom?

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Who but Constance!—divine Constance!

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: (Aside.) Though I despise the fellow!—I—I—but why should I be ruffled?

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: She thought I was making love to herself. (Aside.)

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: And wou'd you have me accessary to the ruin of a young creature?

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: There is no ruin intended;—I have open'd my mind to the lady,—Sir Buzzard is my friend, and I only solicit your interest; I would marry Constance.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: No ruin intended! could a greater curse befal a young creature than to marry you!—who are you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Who am I, madam! a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: I don't mean to asperse your birth, Sir; but is not your ruling passion play; your principal dependance cards and dice; your most intimate connections jockies, grooms, gamecocks, and race-horses? I am surprized you could look up to her.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: My fortune and family entitle me to look up to any woman.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Then it must be merely to look up; you are, no doubt, one of Fortune's favourites, and her favours follow you;—you have large estates in expectancy, and considerable rents in Bath, Wells, Scarborough, Southampton and Margate; nay, more, you have as many agents as the first landed gentleman in the country.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: I don't understand this treatment.

sp.speaker: La. Flip.
sp.p:
Your connexions, manners and conversation
would be perfectly agreeable to Constance's turn of mind;—her respect for religion, her morality, philosophy, and knowledge of the belles lettres, would exactly coincide with your studies in the arts and sciences of play.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Arts and sciences of play—

sp.speaker: La. Flip.
sp.p: I insinuate nothing injurious to your profession; the respect which professors of play receive in preference to all other professors proves it a profession the most liberal, as well as most profitable. (ironically.)

sp.speaker: Cheat.
Lady Flip.
sp.p: You say the debt of honour shall be cancelled. Are you aware that Constance has bestowed her favours on young De Courcy, of York.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Yes; and that his passion for play was cooled at the last York races, which obliged him to take a trip to France for the recovery of his finances.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: And his losses she imputes to a conspiracy between you and those friends of yours, who were the ostensible winners, and to whom you introduced him;—I sear you have no chance.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Chance!—leave me to that;—I have often won with the odds against me; then she is a beggar, but my passion is disinterested.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p:
And pray now, how much of the
uncle's debt of honour is to be paid by this parental kindness to the niece?—I see into the scheme,—and here comes the unfortunate sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I understand your ladyship desired to speak with me.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: To inform you, my dear, of some engagements, but particular business calls me away for a few minutes, so I leave you to entertain Mr. Cheaterly. Exit Lady Flippant.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: (Aside.) Her modest blush puts even my impudence out of countenance!—your solicitude, madam, to avoid me, so strongly indicates apathy to my addresses, I almost dread the possibility of convincing you I am sincere;—do not turn from me in scorn; I may have some claim upon your gratitude, though no interest in your heart.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Gratitude! Oh! Your absence, Sir, I must insist on; I will not, in future, be persecuted by your presumption!

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: I acknowledge my weakness in pursuing the impulse of my passion; reason checks me, but such is the imperious violence of my affection, that even your scorn increases my desires, by making you lovely in the midst of anger, and the blessing I sigh for, appears still more valuable, more worthy pursuit, from the distant prospect you give me of the possession.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Prospect, Sir!

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Yes, madam, prospect.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: You will be pleased, Sir, to withdraw— walks disconcerted. you are insolent.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Insolent! a hard word, madam, to a man who prefers you to every other woman,—I may be bold, madam, but—

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I repeat it, you are insolent.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: I am calm, madam; I know the impediment to my happiness, young lady, and have spirit to remove it.—Insolent! ha; you prefer a clandestine correspondence with a bankrupt in fame and fortune, to the generous addresses of a man, honoured with your uncle's approbation, and independent of the world.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: The engagements of my heart—but I will not weep— (wiping her eyes) —Sir—you have, with a base and mean cowardice, dared to traduce a generous, unsuspecting youth, whose fortune you have assisted to ruin, but whose honour you can never taint;—a youth who, if present, you would not dare to look on withouttrembling. (going.)

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: What's the matter now?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Enquire of that gentleman, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: What a life I lead! my mind kept in a continual fever, you and your aunt are a perpetual ague to me;—her hot fits of levity, and your cool fits of prudery, operate alternately, and I am tortured by you from morning till night.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I must tell you, Sir, that since your house cannot afford me protection, I shall leave it; and, though destitute of fortune, I know where to apply for an asylum. Ex. Constance.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p:
"I know where to apply for an asylum!"—She cannot have a knowledge of our secret, or I would suppose she meant the Chancery;
a man must now pay as much attention to his ward, as if she was his child.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: True, and what adds to the grievance, if a young fellow marries an heiress, he is obliged to settle her fortune on herself, though, perhaps, her person was a secondary object,—I shall never succeed here, Sir Buzzard.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Pish, why not succeed; a hundred to one but all she has said is pretence,—you know nothing of women's subtilty; they smile, they frown, they laugh, they weep, they move but to deceive us, and lay a snare in every article of their dress.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: De Courcy is the object of her choice.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Why afraid of De Courcy? his friends at York races plucked the poor devil of a pigeon so bare, they scarcely left him feathers to fly into France.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: I was present;—may I depend on your assistance?

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Is not our bargain concluded?—on the day of your marriage with my niece, you return me my mortgages, the bill of sale upon my horses, and an acquittance of all demands.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Depend upon it—I have pledg'd my honour;—assist me, and I will pursue my game, though she keeps me at bay every step.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Cheaterly, I must look about me; I came down here for the recovery of my health, and am suffering under a precipitate consumption of my purse. Do you think the young clergyman plays fair?

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: You mean parson Spruce; could you suspect a divine?

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p:
Why, yes; I do suspect your divines
in their own hair, and boots, many of them I believe have thrown off morality with their wigs, and kicked away religion with their shoes.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: But Dr. Spruce has three hundred a year in the church—he won a cool fifty from me.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: A fifty! I lost more to him than would purchase four years of his income.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Do you want cash? I can lend you a hundred; here (gives him a note) with friends money should be a common commodity.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Why I lost this note to Parson Spruce last night—he gave me a fifty and took it.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Aye, Oh, I had it from him, he gave it to me for a bill on London.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Here comes Colonel Staff and old Ordeal yoked together, very naturally, as two asses should be;—I despise them both: the Colonel never served abroad, yet he prates as bold as if he had experienced half a dozen foreign campaigns.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: And is poor and proud.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Yes, but hopes to mend his fortune by marrying my sister; I wish him success, that they may mutually torment each other.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Mark Ordeal, he is not a less extraordinary character than the Colonel, the fellow was a foundling, and never knew his parents, but having acquired a fortune by trade, impudently insults his betters, by preaching what he calls generosity.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p:
O, confound his generosity, he is always setting a bad example with his charities,
relieving widows, providing for orphans, and portioning off young maidens; though ignorant as a Hottentot, he has got himself rank'd among the literati, and sets up for a philosopher—the fellow has come into life through as many shapes as an Orkney Barnacle, he was first a block, then a worm, and is now a goose.

div3.stage: Enter Colonel STAFF, and Mr. ORDEAL.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! I have been accusing Ordeal of avarice, and he denies the charge.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: I do, avarice, though too often an attendant on age, is a vice foreign to my nature; no man can accuse me of accumulating money by unjust means, or of hoarding it when in my possession; whereas avarice is a dropsy of the mind—a disease that irritates and increases by the means used to assuage its thirst.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Have you not refused to lend me a mere trifle, and being rich, is not that a proof of avarice.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Hear me;—I consider myself an agent, bound to answer for the distribution of that wealth with which heaven has bless'd my industry—the charge of avarice is more applicable to the spendthrift than the prudent, the spendthrift grasps at every man's property; yet no man is accounted avaricious who conforms to the custom of dissipation; though the spendthrift raises his rents, and starves his tenantry—borrows money and ruins his friend, or runs in debt, and makes bankrupts of his tradesmen, if he drives a carriage—keeps a train of servants, plays, drinks, and plunges into vice, the world will call him a damn'd generous fellow—I speak my mind—that's my way.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Well, Colonel, how goes on your affair with my fantastical sister? She is a jilt, Colonel.—I hate a jilt.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: She will soon surrender, I have got possession of the counterscarp▪ and shall shortly set up the standard of matrimony upon the crown of the—

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Horn work—Eh?

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: The widow has a considerable share of the toujours gai in her composition.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Too much to promise constancy; but then you old bachelors have such winning ways—but Colonel, keep a centinel on my sister—time and possession are two dangerous pioneers; the first moulders the cement by degrees; and the other saps the foundation.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Then the widow is so frank, degagé and good natured, she may grant favors from charity and sensibility, which other women would refuse from principle, or the prejudice of education.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: What Mr. Cheaterly has advanced, contains profound gravity of judgment; but my Clary shall have no modern education, I have engaged a master to teach her the Classics, to manure the soil by cultivating the seeds of virtue;—yes, I will have Clary cultivated; for she is innocence itself: free from the bias of example, she is guided only by the impulse of pure nature.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: A young lady could not have a more dangerous preceptor, the impulse of pure nature will produce every evil that can arise from the politest education.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p:
I am convinc'd she is delicate as the ermine,
which would die to preserve the snowy whiteness of its fur.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Well said, my old friend, amorous as May, though grey as December.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Grey! Nay, let me tell you, Colonel; though snow has fallen upon the mountain, there is sunshine in the valley—Clara is an Aurora Borealis, a blaze in the regions of frigidity.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Ordeal, seriously, now, are you going to marry this ward of your's for love?

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Seriously, I love the girl as I love my life; but if I did not, having no relations nor friends to whom I owe any obligation, I am determined to make her my heir.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: And no doubt she will bring you an heir in return, and then bury you.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Bury me!—Granted: when I sleep peaceable under the green turf, let her marry some honest young fellow, and their children shall bear my name.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: A good way this to raise a family without trouble.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Family, I understand your sneer, I was a foundling it is true, and cannot boast ancestry; yet I have a heart susceptible of the tender feelings and sweet solicitudes of humanity. Though I cannot claim relations of particular descriptions, I know Adam and Eve were our primitive parents, therefore, consider the world one common family, and hold myself bound to all mankind by ties of fraternal love.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: And your family kindness is not confined to your brothers, but extends to your sisters too.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p:
Clara's father was my friend, we serv'd our apprenticeship together, set up in the same
branch of trade, he failed, and died poor, but I prospered—he was a worthy soul, and I never speak of him without tears. (weeps.)

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Ah! very good, Sir Buzzard; because the father was his juvenile friend he would marry the daughter in his old age.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: A pretty excuse for a vicious appetite.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Hear, hear!

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Clara's father, when on his death-bed, bequeathed her to me as a legacy, it was a bequest of confidence, and I esteem it more than if it had been a million: he bequeathed her to me an infant without a mother, without relations, without friends, without fortune.—Now, though rich in the liberal gifts of nature, who hath endowed her with an exuberant hand, yet being poor in worldly substance, she hath but few attractions for a husband; the knight errants of these days are Argonauts—this is the golden age and every thing is bought and sold.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Spoke in the true spirit of commerce, my old merchant.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Let me tell you, Sir Knight, the spirit of commerce is the best spirit in the nation; we merchants live by barter and sale it is true, but take this with you, sir, probity is our principle, and our character nice as a lady's.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p:
Here comes my moiety of mortality—here comes the origin of two thirds of my complaints, with my widow'd sister, the Colonel's tormentor that is to be—see, they smile at some mischief in embryo—Ah, candied ginger, sugar on the outside, fire within, sweet on the palate, biting on the tongue. Ordeal keep a
strict eye upon pure nature, the aloe is most bitter when green▪ (going.)

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Nay, stay, Sir Buzzard.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Stay, and my wife coming! excuse me, I avoid her as I would an epidemic complaint. Exit.

div3.stage: Enter Lady FLIPPANT SAVAGE and Widow VOLATILE.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Are you here, Colonel? I follow you as the little bird does the cuckoo—Mr. Ordeal, your most obedient, how is pretty Clara, and when are we to call her Mrs. Ordeal.—You rear her quite a domestic animal, she is never seen abroad.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Nor at home, sister, not even at the windows.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: He fears the sun would spoil her complexion.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: She hath indeed a lovely complexion, glowing and bright as the Tyrian dye, not a modern local blush, that hides shame instead of discovering it; but ruddy health moving in varied tints—the lily and the rose vying for pre-eminence on her cheek!—O she is pure nature!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But when introduced to life those roses will blow, those lilies will fade.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: She shall never get into any life, but where they may blow and fade naturally—her real face shall never be concealed under a counterfeit; some ladies coin complexions, and should be punished for high treason in defacing beauty.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Bravo, old Ordeal! bravo!

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p:
I reprobate imposition of charms! a reverend bishop declared to me he was married
two years before he saw his wife's face, and that was by accident.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: I am astonished a gentleman of your age can be so scandalous, so malicious, but it is the nature of wasps to retain their buz after they have lost their sting.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Our gaiety provokes their spleen; these ancient gentlemen rail at women for speaking scandal, yet resort in groupes to every place of public entertainment, ogl'ng with their telescope eyes to discover blemishes on beautiful objects—now here's a piece of antiquity!

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: I have not pretended to juvenality since the crow's feet appeared near my eyes; nay, don't bite your lips, widow, lines will appear in the skin after thirty, and are the harbingers to wrinkles.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: The chocolate is ready, my lady.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Sister, let us in—Mr. Cheaterly—

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: I attend your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Can I pay my respects to Constance, my old friend's daughter?

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: You will probably find her in the study—poor Constance takes the humbleness of her situation too much to heart.

div3.stage: Exit L. Flip. Cheat. and Wid.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Colonel, I knew the father of Constance intimately, a stout fellow and served his country long and well—he served abroad—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Hem!

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p:
Strict honour was his principle—but alas, he experienced that was not the medium
to promotion-—so finding carpet soldiers like you promoted over his head, he went to India.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: This widow of mine, Ordeal, hath a prolific flow of wit and spirits.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Yes, and egad I thought she struck you dumb—she has a prolific tongue too, sharp as the arrow of a Bornean Indian, and tipp'd with poison; your union with her will be happy—perfectly happy—though I recollect she compared you to a cuckoo, a bird of omen; yes, a cuckoo is a very ominous bird—pray, Colonel, is the widow skilled in augury?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Damn your cuckoo! but your speaking of augury reminds me of a circumstance at the siege of Prague—a flock of rooks—

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: I must go pay my compliments to Constance▪

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: At the siege of Prague—when the Prussian grenadiers advanced (holds Ordeal)

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Were you at the siege, Colonel?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: My regiment was there—I have served my country.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Oh, yes, you have done great service to your country—at home—by censuring those who have fought for her abroad.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: SIR, I must say you presume too far.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I saw your ladyship and admired, and if that be presumption, who is free from it? admiration naturally produced a more tender emotion—I communicated my feelings to Mrs. Muslin;—Mrs. Muslin reported them to your ladyship, and your ladyship, with a mind, liberal as your person is elegant, permits me to throw myself at your feet.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: You have misconstrued the liberty I allowed—my house is always open to persons of fashion, and as a visitor only I expected you.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Nay, madam, your privy counsellor informed me I should be admitted into the interior cabinet, and your principal lady in waiting introduced me in form accordingly.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: And shall I call her now, sir, to shew you the way back? (aside) pleasant impudent fellow.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You are not so cruel—I see pardon beaming from your eye, and frolic smiling on your cheek.

p.hi: And should I pardon, from that instant, the servile suppliant, now at my feet, would lose all sense of obligation, and from the mistress's slave aspire to be her tyrant.
I neither desire to be slave or tyrant, but to love upon equal terms—you consent—I read it in your eyes—and I am secret as the grave.
Secret you may be, but it is not the mere colour of reputation can protect a woman's honor.—I might perhaps carry on an intrigue with secrecy, but my mind—

Upon my soul I have no design upon your ladyship's mind, my heart is captivated; and if I did not totally misunderstand my good friend, and your ladyship's very good friend, Mrs. Muslin, a certain person, (whom modesty will not permit me to name) is not totally indifferent in your opinion

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: (within.) Grace, where is your lady?

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Sir Buzzard's voice!

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: (within) My lady, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Yes, your lady, ma'am!—

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: (speaking very loud) She is in her own room, sir, but I believe not yet dress'd—I'll let her know you want her, sir.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: As I hope to be saved, here is my master, and in one of his gruff humours, quite in a tantrum—the gentleman cannot go out that way—follow me.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Into the next room—make haste

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I go, perhaps into the interior cabinet—This alarm I trust will convince your ladyship that in love, as in war, delays are dangerous—Go on, Mrs. Grace.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: What an infernal life I lead!

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: What has rais'd the storm now?

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Why ask!—you know I am married—and married to you—I am my own master, and hate impertinent questions—I have lost my money—I am glad of it.—Oh! I wish I had never married

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: (sighs) And I, with all my heart▪

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Yet you leaped at my offer—you were glad to snatch at me—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Who I? I was seduced into the match!—have I not brought reputation to your house, sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Reputation to my house!—you have turn'd my house topsy turvy; inside out; you have irritated me into a complication of complaints, and reduced my fortune to galloping decay—have fretted me down to a mere skeleton.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p:
Sir, some respect is due to my birth;—I am daughter to a nobleman, and
till honoured with my hand, your family could not boast a drop of blood in their veins.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: No blood in their veins! I, indeed have lost both flesh and blood; no blood in my veins!—Have I not lent your brother money—your uncle, money—your cousins money!—which of your honourable, or right honourable relations are out of my debt?—If I had no blood in my veins, how the devil have you and yours bled me so plentifully?

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: I despise your meanness—

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Your family are leeches—I could never shake them off.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Sir, your connexion with me was an honor, which with all your land and wealth, you had no right to expect. What was your family before your union with me?

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Men and women.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Could they boast antiquity?

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Yes, my grandfather lived to ninety—my father to eighty-six.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: You married me—

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: To perpetuate my family—are you satisfied?

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: No, I am not satisfied.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: I know it, I know it.—I know it.

p.hi: My ancestors can be traced to the Normans—the Danes—the Saxons.
Which only proves you have sprung from pirates and invaders; but what is it to me if you were related to the Picts, the Scots, or the Romans?—I am a Savage!
Yes, you are a savage indeed—
And the Savages let me tell you, are the oldest and purest blood in the country.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: (aside) How shall I get rid of him—Sir Buzzard, you don't intend to stay here I hope?

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: You hope so, do you?—I am glad of that, then here I shall have a comfortable nap. (sits down and composes himself)

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: (aside) I'll raise the spirit of contradiction to send him off (draws a chair and sits by him) now that is kind, thanks for your company, and I'll read, or sing a lullaby to compose you; shall I kiss you?—come now, smile my dear. (takes off his hat)

sp.speaker: Sir Buz:
sp.p: I hate smiling, smiling is the cunning covering of deceit, (rising) and kissing—am I in a habit of constitution for kissing?

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Am not I your wife?

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: I feel you are—do not roll your basilisks—they have lost their fascinating powers.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: But you shall not go—

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Not go!—I am master of my own house!

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Then I will be mistress of my time;—I may find a companion.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: With all my heart—a woman who would keep her husband at home, is worse than a corn on his foot, there is no stirring at ease for her!—O that mine were cut off.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: You will go before me though, I shall wear weeds for my love—your face looks this instant pale as marble, and I can see "Here lieth Sir Buzzard Savage," written on your forehead.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: I am ill it is true.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Ill! you have a mortal blackness under your eyes.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Eh! What!

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Do not stare so—it alarms me!

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: My head swims!—I feel a palpitation here, just upon my temple.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: A dangerous symptom.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: I know it, and you are glad of it. Oh, Lord! I shall presently be enrolled on Death's list of Bath patients, who die where they come to live for the recovery of their health. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Now to deliver my poor distressed swain from confinement. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Nay, my nonpareil—my sweetest, dearest of all girls, you may believe every word I say. Lady FLIPPANT appears listning at a door in the scene. I have lov'd you—

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Love me!—dear sir!—Well, whether you speak truth or no, I like to hear you say so—yet, I fear you are false-hearted, it was my lady you came to visit.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Your lady! no, no, child, you were the object, and I got myself introduced to the lady, that I might with more ease become intimate with the maid.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Cannot believe that—my lady is much hand somer than I—What a fine complexion!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Mere rouge!

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: White teeth!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: For which she's obliged to the Dentist—

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Charming hair!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: All false.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Then, what polite conversation!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Psha, child she has not the native bloom of your cheeks, the nectarine of your lip, the pearl of your teeth, the natural curl of your tresses, nor the wit of your imagination.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: (aside) How I likes to hear him praise me and abuse my lady!—and you really love me?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Most devoutly—could we not retire to a more private chamber? (shews a purse.)

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Swear you'll not be false hearted.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: By Jupiter, Venus, Cupid, and all the Gods and Goddesses, never (shakes the purse)

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Then hear me swear (lays her hand upon the purse) by this purse (takes it) I like you.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Take it my girl—take it.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: And by this ring, I'll (lays her hand on his ring)

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: My dear don't swear so often—but kiss me hussey—I have a secret to tell you.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: A secret! but may not that secret speak for itself hereafter, and discover all. (Lady Flippant comes forward.) Dear ma'am you can't think how the gentleman has been praising your ladyship's complexion, teeth, hair, and I don't know what.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Yes, I was praising your ladyship's—I—I—I—don't know what.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: There's no impediment now, sir, to your retiring, and I request you will instantly withdraw.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: For the present I submit to your rigid and peremptory sentence;—it is my way never to deny or palliate my faults. When I travel in pursuit of pleasure, I always take a view of such beautiful seats as lie before me, and for the life of me, I could not help casting an eye on this little snug box, which lay so convenient to your ladyship's mansion-house. Ex. Welford.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: I hope your ladyship will excuse me;—I thought I was doing no harm,—I thought your ladyship dismissed the gentleman, and your ladyship knows we chambermaids have the same claim to our lady's cast lovers, as to their cast cloaths. Exit Grace.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Order chairs, and tell my sister I'll attend her to—Devil take the fellow, yet I admire him for his impudence.

div3.head: SCENE III.
div3.stage: Enter NICHOLAS and DOUGLAS, disguised in a shabby Highland Dress.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: And so you were recommended by old Corderius, the schoolmaster, to teach our young lady the Latin lingo.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Yes; to instruct her in the reediments of the dead languages.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Dead languages! do you mean the languages spoken in the other world? for ecod she can chatter glibby enough in the living tongue.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: I am to instruct her, man, in Greek and Latin.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Greek and Latin! will not that teach her strology and conjuration? Enter ORDEAL. Here, Sir, is Mr. a—a—What's your name, Scotchey?

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Alexander M'Classic.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: He's Mr. M'Classic, come from Mr. Corderius to learn Miss Clary the dead languages, which he has got alive at his tongue's end.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Here, Sir, are my credentials.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: My friend Corderius gives you an excellent character, young man, for honesty, and literary abilities, and you may begin with your pupil when you please.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: He has began with her already▪

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: You are perfect master of the classics, I presume.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: My father keept an academy, where I first acquired the roodiments, and after I matriculated at Aberdeen; there I made an intimate acquantance with the philosophers, Christian, and Heathen,—the logicians, mathematicians, astronomers, navigators, botanists, chemists, and aw the tribe of nateral philosophers.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: What a number of scholars are in Aberdeen!

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Be silent, fool.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: As to the classics, I am maister of Homer, Xenophon, Sophocles, Seneca, Virgil, Ovid, Terence, Sallust, Livy and Horace.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Have you learned all those gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Silence, you inquisitive puppy.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: I teach them aw, and will make the young lady mistress of them aw.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Mistress of them all! Ecod she'll never remember half of her servant's names! but o' tag, rag, and bobtail; how comes it that with all those scholars you've taught, you go so poorly? Ecod your cloaths are all in jeopardy. He! he! he!

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Silence. Go you, sirrah, and call miss Clara.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: I go—I go—I go—I go—I go—let me see—he teaches musicians, magicians, and physicians—and he'll teach her conjuration and star-gazing—and—mum. Exit Nicholas.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: You are, I presume, Sir, a scholar.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: I never deny my ignorance—it is my misfortune, and a man should only be ashamed of his faults,—I do not understand a word of any language but my native tongue, except a few phrases I have picked up,—but I have read most English authors; born in poverty I was debarred the benefit of a liberal education,—I am candid—that's my way.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: This is a common case.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: No doubt one half of the literati are unlettered, and like light or Birmingham guineas, pass for more than they are worth.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: You intend to mary the lady yourself?

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: And you have secluded her frae company, aw that was judicious—be cautious what men you introduce to her.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Yes; and women too,

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p:
That's right,—recreations which prudence
prohibits at home, and decency denies the exercise of in public, may easily be enjoyed at the preevate house of a confidential friend.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: You are right, there are many obliging, convenient, liberal-hearted, female beauty brokers, who support elegance and expence by trading in a contraband commerce of the sexes. Enter CLARA and NICHOLAS. Well, my girl,—your tutor has given you a lesson, I understand.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Yes, Sir. (Loud knocking).

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Who the devil is at the door?—I believe they have got a battering-ram, and are going to storm us after the manner of the Greeks and Romans. Exit Nich.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Such silks, and rustlings!

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: There are cork rumps—hoops and high heels in the house.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Who knocks at the door?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: They are covered with paint, patches and pomatum.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Who knock'd at the door?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: False hair, curls and perfumes!—don't blame me, they came upon me unawares; I push'd, and they push'd,—but they push'd harder, and overturned me.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Who overturned you?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: They are full of flirtation, and giggling, and bedizened with gauze and ribbands; Lady Savage and her sister, with their long tails sweeping behind.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Lady Savage and her sister! Lady Devil and her imp!—Where are they?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Running all over the house—up stairs and down stairs, to and fro,—in and out—backwards and forwards—round about—here and there, and every where.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: I am not at home,—there is no body at home—we are all out—I'll retire to my closet; you will step with me, Mr. M'Classic, and do you, my lamb, lock yourself up to avoid 'em.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: He, he, he,—here is a bluster,—Ecod we shall have rare sport.

div3.stage: Enter LADY FLIPPANT and the WIDOW.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Where, my dear, in such haste?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Indeed I cannot stay—must I not go, Nicholas?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Yes, you must go,—go—go—go

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Be not alarmed, miss, we are Mr. Ordeal's intimate friends.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Yes, miss, they are our intimate friends.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Come to visit you, my dear.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Yes; they are come to visit us,—my dear.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Where is Sir Ordeal?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Out—out—out (Points to the closet.) (Aside) we shall have swinging fun.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Ladies, farewell. (going.)

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Fie, my dear,—it would be impolite to leave company.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Miss Clary,—Manners makes the man—we are teaching her the Latin lingo.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Are you very happy, my dear, on being on the verge of matrimony?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Speak, my dear. (Lady Flippant, and the Widow, stand on each side of Clara.)

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I cannot say I'm very happy; nor I cannot say I am displeased; I do not wish to be married, nor have I any objection to a husband—Heigho!

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: But to confess the truth, you have no desire to marry Mr. Ordeal, he is such an old fellow; though if addressed by a handsome, wealthy, good natured youth, you'd—Heigho!

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Do not speak disrespectfully of my guardian—he is very kind to me.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: I approve your prudence in preferring an old lover to a young one; after marriage you will no longer be confined like an infant;—then you will enjoy such pleasure in making his money fly, and in seeing him approach the grave.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But for fear he should live too long, be sure you get him a physician.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: A physician! O, death!

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: My guardian has taught me how a married lady ought to conduct herself.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Let us hear, my dear pretty creature.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I have it by heart; he has taught me, that all young men are cunning and deceitful, and that I must never listen to or believe their flattering tongues; that a man and his wife are one person, and should act as if inspired by one soul!—that a wife should not complain of her husband to her most intimate friends, nor form any connexions without his approbation.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: There's instruction for you; you see we take care of her soul.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
Moreover, he has taught me, that in private a wif should receive no company without
her husband's knowledge, and in public should not think herself protected but by his presence; that she should obey him in all things, and place her highest delight in making him happy.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: These were the duties of a wife in the last century,—but we will instruct you in the duties of a wife, who would cut a figure in the polite circles of the present day▪—Sister, begin.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Must consider matrimony a means to increase liberty, and defy scandal.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Must retain your favourite cicisbeo, confidante, maid servant and footman.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: That will be, I.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: See whom you please, where you please, and when you please.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: That must be very pleasant!—go on.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Must be mistress of your own hours,—turn day into night, and night into day.—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Keep a separate purse, a separate carriage, and a separate bed.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Never attend to oeconomy, but sink, play, and squander your money, to the last shilling, and stretch your husband's credit to the utmost.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Here is work cut out for mantua-makers and milleners.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You must always dissimulate in conversation with your husband, and when you cannot deceive you must insist—if he opposes your will, rant, and laugh at him.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: And if these fail, accuse him of cruelty, sigh, sob, weep, scream out, and fall into fits.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: I can contain no longer!—out of my house!—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Shame! Shame! What, listening to the private conversation of ladies?

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Private conversation! open, abominable instruction,—how can you answer to your conscience, for attempting to poison a young creature's morals!—retire, retire, my lamb.—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Farewell, ladies.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Adieu, pretty Clara.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: And remember our instructions.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Instructions!—down-right libertine principles!—you may laugh, ladies,—you may laugh. Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Perhaps the ladies think their beauty sufficient excuse for their levity,—but ah, they are wrong—naething can atone for want of delicacy, without which there can be nae charms in the face, nae elegance in the person.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ordeal, your most obedient—call'd at your ladyship's house, and Miss Constance inform'd me you were on a visit here.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: We came to see Mr. Ordeal's pure nature, and he has affronted us!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Affronted!—impossible!

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Haud your tongue, lady, haud your tongue!—levity degrades a woman, however her name may be elevated by birth, teetle, or fortin.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Who are you?

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: A man.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Yes, and a scholar ecod!

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: (to the women) Out of my house!

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: I'll prophecy for your comfort, if you marry Clara she'll soon draw a comparison between your winter frown, and the summer smiles of a pretty fellow.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: I despise your prophecy—Oracles have long since ceased; when they existed the devil spoke through them, which may be your ladyship's case.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ordeal, take care, I wear a sword.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: I weer a sword.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Do you daar echo my words?

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Do you daar echo my words?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Knock out his teeth with one of your hard ones.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Rascal (raises his hand).

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Rascal! hear first, and strike after,—you appear an officer, but I am convinced you are nae soldier; touch but a hair o' my heed wi your hand, and the dee'l gang away wi my soul, gin I dinna split you through the crown.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Sir, Sir, shall I bring him the old broad sword.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: There was just such a fellow as this at the Havannah—

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: There were several such fellows at the Havannah, and such fellows only could have beaten the brave fellows who defended it,—were you there?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: My regiment did service there—and if it had not been for a damn'd ague,—but no matter,—I overlook this fellow's insolence,—but Mr. Ordeal, you have been too severe on the ladies

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Too severe on the ladies—I am your echo again—zounds, do you take the man for a Shrove-Tide cock, set up to receive blows without returning them?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Let's go, we are not likely to receive protection from the Colonel.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: I ken, madam, what you are.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Stand off, fellow—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: These are ladies of honour.—

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Their honour, like your courage, is in their own possession, but remember the character of both is in the opinion of others.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Do you hear the fellow?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: He's mad, and not worth notice.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Were I Clara, I should prefer a young Indian, though sure of being his widow; and burning with him in a month, to living with you for an age.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ordeal, you shall answer this—but—

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: But what dare you say?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Say—I say—my immediate duty is to attend the ladies.

div3.stage: Exit Colonel, Lady Flippant and Widow.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: My brave Caledonian! (shakes hands) but here, here, step out and get yourself new rigged— (gives Douglas money).

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Yes, he is out of feather and wants pluming.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: But you, you sirrah, if ever you let those women enter my doors again, out you go—oh, what a fierce beast, and a perilous enemy to the commonwealth, is a wicked woman. Exeunt.

div3.head: SCENE I.
div3.stage: Enter Lady FLIPPANT SAVAGE and GRACE.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: SHALL I introduce the Gentleman, my lady?

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Yes,—no,—yes, Grace.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: I like the gentleman, because he likes your ladyship,—and that shews him a man of taste—I go.— (going)

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Stay, Grace,—let me consider, this interview may be attended with all the ill consequences of an illicit correspondence.—what are you musing on Grace?

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: I am thinking how very ugly Sir Buzzard is in comparison with your ladyship's lover.—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Sir Buzzard's plainness, Grace, is not his worst fault,—it is his peevish asperity of disposition renders him odious to me,—Grace, I will not see this gentleman, it will endanger my reputation.—

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Lay, my lady, but consider, my reputation, my honour is pledged,—he is a delightful creature.—Then consider what an airy, nice dressed gentleman he is—and consider, Sir Buzzard wears flannel under-waistcoats, and swanskin stockings.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Can I ever again face Sir Buzzard?

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p:
If I was your ladyship, I would not face my lover too suddenly,—no, I would recline
upon the sopha,— (sits) lost in thinking,—so,—with my fan shading my face thus, and every thing about me. degagee.—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: You say he waits.—

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Or when the dear man approach'd, turn short—strike him with the full flash of my charms, and scream out. Ah!— (screams and starts up.)

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Are you mad, girl?

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: A thousand pardons, my lady, but protest I am beside myself. Exit. Grace.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: There is no retracting, and I think I will take him by surprise.—I'll keep up the appearance of resentment, and have the satisfaction of hearing him humbly plead for pardon— (sits, with ber back to the door)

div3.stage: Enter GRACE, and WELFORD full dressed.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Now you must acknowledge I am your friend.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: My sweet girl, I do acknowledge it— Exit. Grace. A fine figure! (taps lady Flippant on the shoulder,—she starts) Madam—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Heaven defend me!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Not from an ardent lover!—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: (Aside) I cannot scold the fellow he looks so pleasant!—Pray, Sir, by what warrant do you come here?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I understand from Mrs. Muslin, by warrant from your own lips,—but the warrant is incompleat till your ladyship has affix'd the privy seal to it (offers to kiss her).

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: A married woman can grant nothing without the consent of her husband.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Well thought on; but I do not come unprepared, man and wife are one person, and when a married lady gives me reason to think a tete-a-tete would not be disagreeable, I always take care to bring my authority along with me.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: But suppose a lady should acknowledge your authority;—your inclinations, I imagine, Sir, could not easily be attach'd to a single object.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Yes they could,—though I candidly acknowledge I entertain an affection for the whole sex.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Then there is an individual you prefer to the whole sex?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: There is.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Handsome?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Sensible?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: And you really prefer her—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: If I denied it I should be insincere and unworthy your attention.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: And pray, Sir, may I enquire, who is the favourite fair?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Nay, the less we say, or think of her, the better, she is absent—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Yes, Sir,—I perceive she is absent— (walks about) and you too are absent.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Yes, she is absent,—and—Sir Buzzard is absent, and we are together,—and you are a fine woman,—and I am—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: What, Sir?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: A man,—a young man, not a very ill made man, and a very well dress'd man, with a brisk flow of spirits, a warm heart, and a soul which at this instant vibrates with sensibility.

sp.speaker: Sir Buzzard
sp.p: (within). I say it is false, I left all the papers in London—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: I protest Sir Buzzard is at the door—you must be concealed again—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Unfortunate! (she pushes him in)

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: You cannot get out of that room till I please— (sits)

div3.stage: Enter Sir BUZZARD SAVAGE, and GRACE walking lame.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Oh, mercy, Sir, you have ruin'd me; oh, my lady, my lady, oh, oh, I shall faint with pain; just when I got to the door, there was my master, and not knowing it, I run plump against him, and he trod upon my foot,—oh,—but it is much better.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: (sits) A messenger is come down from London for the title deeds of Prospect Farm,—do you know where they are?

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: What should I know about your musty parchments?

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Why not?—you spend the rents fast enough—but I remember now, they are in a box that lies in the wardrobe in that room, and—

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: La, Sir,—I will get it.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: You are not tall enough to reach it.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p:
But I can stand on a chair, Sir, though I need not do that,—our new footman is in the closet settling your cloaths, Sir.—yes, Sir,—
our new footman, Sir, is in the closet sett'ling your honour's wardrobe, and he'll help me.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: (aside) What can she mean? shall I desire Grace to bring the box out to you?

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: No, let the footman bring it out, I have not seen him yet,—Grace, bid the fellow bring in the box.

sp.speaker: Grace
sp.p: (within) He's taking it down, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Leave it in the closet, I must get some other papers out of the scrutore (rises).

div3.stage: Enter GRACE and WELFORD in a Livery, with a box.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Come, young man, I'll get you my lady's cards for Wednesday's route, and they must be delivered immediately.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: (aside) What a metamorphosis!—you'll be expeditious.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: A good looking fellow;—but stand off;—he is enough to suffocate a man with perfume! What's your name, Civet Cat?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: (in a strong brogue) What's my name? I was christen'd Patrick, your honour.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: An Irishman!—eh,—heav'n knows we had blunders enough in the family before,— (looking on the box) —this is the wrong box.

div3.stage: Exit Sir Buzzard into the closet.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Yes, we have all got into the wrong box (aside).

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: When next we meet— Exit.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Nothing could be more lucky, my lady,—the new livery that came home for your last footman George, lay in the bottom of my master's wardrobe. I must see him safe out—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: This is too mortifying, it hurts my pride—had I met a man of a generous disposition—but here comes my torment, and reflection flies.

div3.stage: Enter Sir BUZZARD with WELFORD's Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: I have found more than I sought for, Lady Flippant;—who am I to thank for this addition to my wardrobe?

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: These cloaths!—you mean these cloaths!—he, he, he,—they are really very pretty cloaths—you like them, my dear?

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: No, I don't like them, my dear; and who the devil did they come from, my dear? and to whom do they belong, my dear?

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Elegant manufacture!—nothing like it made in England.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Where did they come from?

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Paris.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Who owns them?

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: They are your cloaths, my love!—

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Mine! Did you ever see me wear such frippery?

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Yes, yours positively; but I did not intend you should have seen them—they were smuggled.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Smuggled!

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Yes, smuggled from Paris, by my milliner, and sent here for the purpose of ornamenting you, my sweet love!—

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Sweet love!—now that's fulsome—yet thou art my sweet love!

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Am I?— (smiling.)

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Yes, like an apothecary's dose,—my bitter sweet.—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: How ill-natur'd!—but no matter, you shall wear these cloaths at the ball this evening.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: I will not.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: You shall.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Damn me if I do.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Very well, Sir, then I'll send 'em back.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: They shall not be sent back, I begin to like them,—a good colour, and not too gaudy.—I'll keep them.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Keep them!

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Yes, and wear them.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Wear them,—where?

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: At the ball this evening.—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: I fear you will take cold.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: You wish I should take cold, but I will not take cold,—and I will wear the cloaths; you lay out a revenue on your back, and I will, at least for this once, follow your example.—I'll keep the cloaths, and go to the ball in them this evening.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: (Aside.) The smuggled cloaths are fairly forfeited.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Dinner, my Lady!— (seeing the cloaths) bless me!

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: (Apart.) Silence, all is well.—Sir Buzzard you see found the cloaths I ordered Mrs. Muslin to procure him from Paris.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Well, I am sure, Sir, my Lady has fitted you nicely, and I admire her taste, that I do; but will you wear them, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Yes, wear them, Sir!

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Not 'till after dinner, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Directly, Mrs. Prate,—I will surprize the company in them:—let dinner be kept back.

div3.stage: Exit Sir Buzzard with the cloaths.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: It was good luck he did not find the gentleman's sword—yet little matter if he had, for intriguing with an incumbrance about him; but how shall I get him away?

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Poor soul! he must have patience—contrive to convey him through the garden, to a chair, he may pretend he is a servant taken ill, which will blind suspicion.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Well thought on,—my Lady's no fool, but she must be a great fool indeed, who could not make a fool of a husband.

div3.head: SCENE II,—Ordeal's House.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: He, he, he, lack a daisy, Miss Clara—the Scotchman looks gaily in his new cloaths,—he is a brave youth,—what a leg (looks at his leg) —but I have got more of the calf.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Yes, a good deal more calf, Nicholas;—but what can be the reason that while he's teaching me, he sighs as piteously as if in pain,—it goes to my heart to hear him without being able to give him ease.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Why—why—ecod now, Miss Clary, when you speak to me, it makes me sigh, and gives me the heart-burn.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: What would you have me do, good Nicholas?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: What would I have you do? I'll tell you—ecod I cannot—but I'll tell you what the Scotchman ought to do—he,—he ought.—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Ecod, he ought to,—to—Sugar and Honey!—what red lips you have!

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: What ought he to do?—

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: What ought he to do!—why he ought to—how old are you?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Do not tantalize me, Nicholas.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Well, I will tell you, he ought to—bless my eyes, what a fine face she has!—he ought to—he ought to—what pretty buckles yours are!—he ought to,—well, shake hands, I will tell you (takes her hand) soft as sattin,—he ought to—ecod, I should like to do it.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Do what?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: I mean no offence—but he ought to— (kisses his hand) that's what he ought—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Oh, shame, Nicholas,—shame.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: What shame!—listen to me,—and I won't go behind the bush with you—my master is a fool, and thinks nobody knows any thing but himself—Now, when I see a young man and a young lady together,—and hear them sigh, and see them ogle—why, I sigh myself, and I—I—ecod, I know what's what.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And what is it you know, Nicholas?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: That the Scotch scholard loves you, and that you like the Scotch scholard—I'ze been in love, and I'ze never think of it, but—Oh, but I can not tell you how it disturbs me— (whistles.)

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And I am disturbed too—heigh ho!

lg.head: SONG.
lg.l: What wakes this new pain in my breast?
This sense that lay dormant before?
Lie still, busy flutt'rer, and rest,
The peace of my bosom restore.
Why trickles in silence the tear,
This sighing—ah! what does it mean?
This mixture of hope and of fear,
Where once all was mild and serene.—
Now warms and then freezes my heart,

div3.stage: Enter ORDEAL and DOUGLAS, in a neat Scotch Dress.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Clara, your tutor tells me, you make an astonishing progress in your Grammar, and I am to hear you speak a lesson,—bring chairs, Nicholas (they sit).

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Ha you got your Grammar, lady?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I have been studying my last lesson (takes a Grammar from her pocket).

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Be seated, lady, (they sit).

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p:
Modest creature!—how the blush mantles on her cheek!—don't be ashamed, Clary—Mac Classic (takes Douglas aside) what a subject
for speculation—she is an orange tree, possessing at once the sprightly verdure of the spring, the sweet blossom of the summer, and the ripe fruit of autumn. It revives me to look on her.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: It revives us to look on you.—

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: What think you of her eyes,—they shoot arrows of desire into the heart, but on her lips lies an honied salve to heal the wound.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: (agitated) Will you hear her repeat a lesson?

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: See her mouth, a door of coral, opening to a colonade of pearl.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Then her bosom, your honour.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Where the devil is the fellow going? (shakes him).

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: (aside) My spirits are so agitated, I shall betray myself.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Come, my lamb—begin.—there is a mild creature, wax of my own fashioning, and I have moulded her into the very temper of my affections.—

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: She can give you Latin for every thing about you.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Restrain your tongue, sirrah. Go on with your lesson, sweetest, and never mind this fellow.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: (Tenderly) Amo, I love, (looks at Douglas) amas, thou lovest, (looks at Ordeal) amat, he loves!

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: (Sighs). Oh!

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Amamus, we love. Oh! (sighs)

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: He, he, he, amo—I love!

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Silence, rascal!—but, Mac Classic, are the first lessons in Lilly's grammar upon love?

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Aw grammars begin wi it, Sir—because love is the primoeval principle of nature.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: He, he, he!

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Out of the room, you scoundrel!

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: I go, zir. Amo, I love, amo, you love, amo, he loves, amo, we love,—he, he, he!

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Shall we proceed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: If you please.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: There are three poor people below you desired to call.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: I shall return directly.— (Nicholas following) Where are you going? Stay here,—Clara may want something—you'll give her a new lesson now, Mr. M'Classick—I think she has got enough of amo and amas.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Zooks! he's jealous, zure as a gun, and left me here to watch you—but ecod, I'll be no spoil-sport—so teach away—I love, you love—he loves. Exit Nicholas.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: What are you musing on?—I like to hear your instructions when we are alone.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: (aside) To seduce such innocence would be damnable; when you are married to Mr. Ordeal, my instructions will no longer please,—you love him?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I do indeed, as much as if he was my father,—but I never think of him when you are present.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Then you love him from gratitude?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
Just so!—could I have any other motive
—If there be any other kind of love, I wish you'd let me know it.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: There is another kind,—give me your hand—there is a love known by its effects, it beats on the pulse, trembles on the breath, gives eyes to the thoughts, and thoughts to the eyes.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: O la! then I'm sure you are in love, for your eyes speak and laugh,—why did you touch my hand?—indeed—indeed, I'm afraid I have taken it from you—I hope there's no danger in it.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Love is the child of desire, nurs'd by delight—weaned by inconstancy, consumed by neglect, kill'd by dissembling, and buried by ingratitude.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: How cruel to kill it.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: But then 'tis the parent of jealousy, the disuniter of friendship, and cause of disobedience; an arbitrary tyrant of the mind, that triumphs over wisdom, tramples upon prudence, and vanquishes even virtue.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: O, you fright me with that description.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: But where virtue is the basis of this passion, it produces the utmost happiness enjoyed on earth, and gives mortals a taste of heaven!

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Now that is delightful! and to tell you the truth I have heard my guardian speak of it, but I could never feel it in his hand as I did in your's; he says—"love is fire full of cold—honey full of gall—and pleasure full of pain;"—but I see he knows nothing of the matter;—are you really in love?

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Yes, my dear, deeply—deeeply;—but why do you ask?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Because—

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Here comes Mr. Ordeal.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: (Aside) I wish he was in Jericho.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Very well—very well—here Nicholas!—where's the rascal? Clara, my dear, seek him, and give orders for dinner, there's a good girl. (Kisses her hand).

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Heigho! (looks at Douglas)—(to Ordeal) I obey, Sir. Exit Clara.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: An amiable, modest creature, Mr. M'Classic—nothing ardent in her disposition, has no more idea of love than an infant, yet a charming fertilizing constitution, but chaste as ice,—"her heart like the salamander—cold, cold, in the midst of flame."

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Virtue beams in her een, and animates her countenance; like the finishing touches of the painter, it enlivens the portrait, and increases the beauty of the object.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Poetically conceiv'd, and prettily pronounc'd;—yes, she shrinks from the touch like the sensitive plant—you have a prolific imagination, Mr. M'Classic, considering you come from a northern climate (viewing Douglas) —yet Mr. M'Classic, there is no judging of a woman's chastity, who has never been in the way of temptation.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Very true, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: And women are virtuous in proportion to the temptations they withstand.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: A just conclusion, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Then you think it would be difficult to find a young inexperienced girl proof against promises, sighs and tears—and who could withstand the cunning insinuations of a lover.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Certainly, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Well, I think differently; I think I could trust Clara—but she's a nonpareil—yes, cool as a cucumber in a hot bed—yet not prone to vegetation—but M'Classic, I have an experiment to make, and you must assist me.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Command me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Clara I think is a pure lamb.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Sir, there can be no doubt; but you were speaking of an experiment, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: I have fortified her mind with morals, which will prove a shield to her by day, and a breast-plate by night.—But the experiment—you must be my instrument.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: In what respect, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: To sound the depth of her inclinations,—to feel how the pulse of her affection beats towards me.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: If she should not like me—but that is a point for future consideration—if she should like me, I will marry her in the morning.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Marry her, Sir!

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Yes, marry her, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: And in the morning. O my heart! and must I lose her after all?

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: In the morning—I have had a special licence sometime—yes, she loves me—I know she loves me—and soon as we have dined, I will go to Sir Buzzard's, to engage him and his friends to attend the ceremony. In the mean time you must try the experiment—come-in to dinner, and I'll give you further instructions.

div3.head: SCENE I. Sir Buzzard's.
div3.stage: Enter Sir BUZZARD and CHEATERLY. Sir Buzzard in Welford's Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: CONSIDER, Sir Buzzard, we are in danger of a discoveey every ininstant.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: What can I do?—Would you have me court the girl for you? Besides, this business raises a qualm in my conscience.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Conscience!

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Yes, conscience!—my conscience cannot boast such extensive latitude and longitude as your's,—you have a convenient conscience, it stretches or contracts like India rubber; your conscience is a servant of all work—which you discharge at a moment's warning.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: May the fire of a platoon never again raise my spirits, but it would be better for a man to attack a breach daily and on a forlorn hope, than to sit down before a coquet.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: "Have you ever attacked a breach, Colonel?"

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: You hear he has attacked a widow, and upon a forlorn hope."

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I say, Sir, your sister is a coquet.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: I say she is a downright jilt. He who confides in the sex will be deceived—I despise them.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Yet keep a girl in a corner.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: "But not from affection to the girl, I keep her because it pleases my humour, and vexes my wife." You know the sex but superficially; there is my rib, when we married, she was all delicacy and good humour, and from her smooth behaviour and oily tongue, I considered her a miracle of goodness. But the wind soon veer'd about, and before the end of the honey-moon blew a rank storm.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: "Talking of storms."

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: "Hear me out—Upon refusing to indulge her in some fashionable subscriptions, there was a total eclipse of the amiable, her passion swell'd like a roaring sea, producing nothing but fury, outrage and noise."

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: I forgive you, madam,—I forgive you—being determined to marry Clara in the morning.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Ordeal, I understand they have been abusing you—but their best friends cant 'scape their malignity—they have tongues of charcoal, with which they are for ever blackening or burning characters.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: I shall, immediately set off with my bride for London, from whence we will proceed on the grand tour.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Have not I heard you exclaim against the grand tour.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p:
You have heard me exclaim against sending our youth abroad without a proper controul. You have heard me say, that on such expeditions they too often contaminate their native virtue and constitutions, by bartering the honest habits acquired in old England, for the
gew-gaw ornaments, and despicable effeminacies of the Continent.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Ordeal, what retinue do you travel with?

sp.speaker: Cheat.
