sp.p: The young Scotchman, Pure Nature's tutor, no doubt will make one.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: I wish he may not make two; I speak my mind, Ordeal.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What, the Colonel's friend! split you through the crown?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: She is at it again—madam, you should recollect.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Then I suppose you will no longer restrain her taste in dress—but allow her to throw off her present thin attire, and appear like a fashionable christian,—in feathers and a hoop.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: A hoop! no—it makes a woman appear like a walking sphere, encircled from the nadir to the meridian—and if the effeminacy of the men was not so well known, one would be apt to imagine that the women were all in a state of—But I will not speak my mind now,—though it is my way.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Coffee is served in the saloon, madam.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Have you seen Miss Constance? (aside to the servant).

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I believe, Sir, she is reading in the garden. Exit Servant.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Sir Buzzard, I admire your dress,—you look as fine—as—as the King of Prussia in wax-work.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: (To the widow) shall I have the honor of your hand, Madam?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: No, Sir, I shall never give my hand to a man who has lost my good opinion.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: (To Sir Buzzard) —Do you hear that?

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: After her.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: After her purse you mean.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Capricious woman! (running turns round). —I once knew a Major—

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Know the Widow, man.—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: A Major in the forty-second.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Away with you. (they push him out).

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: You will excuse me to the ladies—Constance you hear is in the garden, I will seek her, and for the last time plead my passion, but if she perseveres in rejecting my addresses, I have your consent to carry her by stratagem.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Carry her off any way and I will be satisfied.— Exit Sir Buzzard.

div3.head: SCENE II.—A Grotto: Constance discover'd sitting, sleeping, with a handkerchief overher face—a book near her.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Asleep!—to disturb her would offend delicacy—and I must sooth her,—I will sit here till she wakes, here comes one of the servants. (Retires).

div3.stage: Enter WELFORD. (His sword under his arm.)

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p:
How my landlady will laugh to see me thus caparison'd,—a woman sleeping, by the God of Love!—what a fortunate fellow am I!
—no sooner does one adventure vanish than another presents itself to my view—how gently she breathes,—the gale is reviving,— (she sighs) a sigh of sensibility,—poor soul!—it were pity she should sigh in vain. Yes, I will see her face. (takes off the handkerchief) O, Heaven's!—it is Constance—my life!—my heaven!— (embraces her).

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Help!—oh, help!—

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Unhand the lady, villain!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: O, heavens, it is De Courcy!—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Ha! is it you? I have met my blessing and my curse.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: De Courcy!—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I have been your dupe, Sir, and I know it.—Am well inform'd of those combinations by which you defrauded me,—and am determin'd, Sir, to give the law it's course.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: I scorn to retort your assertions,—you have been a dupe to your own folly. Pride, and high founding language but ill suit with the meanness of your appearance, assumed for the purpose of some low intrigue,—metamorphose into a gentleman, and I'll enforce satisfaction for this insolence. Exit Cheaterly.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: O, I shall faint.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: My dear love,—pardon the momentary neglect into which passion led me.—I have been but one day in England—tomorrow I should have gone for York,—my soul was all impatience to see you.—

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: What, in a livery!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p:
A livery—yes,—it is a disguise I own, worn for a purpose I'll not attempt to palliate
or justify—but your appearance like a heavenly vision inspires me with virtuous thoughts.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I do not urge an explanation which must increase your confusion.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I will explain all another time.—Here comes some of the family.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: These alarms will ruin my constitution,—it was fortunate I took bark this morning, or my whole nervous system would be shaken to pieces.—Where is this gentleman?—Cheaterly tells me a stranger has been rude to you, have you turn'd him out, Patrick?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: (To Ordeal) Sir, I shall send a letter to your house immediately, to which I implore your attention—I am wretched, you were my father's friend.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Madam, if I was not, I am a man, and every thing that affects my fellow-creatures concerns me.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Patrick,—do you hear?—no answer,—I shall never recover my health,—don't irritate me, rascal.—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Rascal!—to whom do you address yourself?

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: To you, scoundrel.—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Why, you despicable,—that epithet again, and this sword.—

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: This is no Irishman!—what the devil is become of your brogue?—who are you?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: A gentleman!—

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p:
A gentleman! ha, ha, ha, this is good!—a gentleman in a livery!—but which are you?
a gentleman in waiting, or a gentleman of the road?

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Ah, ah! I now see how I came by the new suit, smuggled from Paris.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: The servant is mad, and Sir Buzzard has caught the contagion.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: I have it here. (Striking his head.)

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: What have you there?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Nothing that I know of, upon my honor.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Nothing in your master's head! How dare you joke with your betters, young man?

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: I shall be the laughing-stock of fools and jest of the malignant.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Oh, dear, dear, sure there is no harm done! It is all my fault,—Miss Constance is ready to break her heart;—you must know, Sir, I was the only person in the house who knew this gentleman, he is her lover, and he wheedled me, and wheedled me, till I consented to bring him into the house, and so I shut him into my lady's closet.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: The girl tells the truth.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: He is a gentleman, and you shut him up in your lady's closet. (To Sir Buzzard.) Now, I see what you conceive in your head.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: And so, Sir, my lady coming in, the gentlemen was oblig'd to lie close.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: And he wheedled you, and wheedled you,—"And he lay close,—Eh"—and he never saw your lady?

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Never saw her, as I hope to be saved!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You hear the girl swear.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: O, it's plain there was nothing between them.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: "Nothing between them indeed, Sir, that is the naked truth." Exit Grace.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Then give me leave, Sir, to enquire who you are? and what are your pretensions to visit my niece?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: As to my pretensions, Sir, nothing can be better founded,—I love the lady,—but what is still more material, the lady has long since confess'd that she loves me.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Candid and open.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: And your name is De Courcy?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: To that name I was born, but an old good natured uncle taking it into his head to visit elizium—in obedience to his will, and in gratitude for sixteen hundred pounds a year, I now bear the name and arms of Welford.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: You seem an honest fellow, worthy the love of Constance.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: What is his honesty to me? I am to inform you, Sir, the father of Constance is dead; I am her natural guardian, and you shall never have my consent to marry her.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: May I never obtain her consent, if ever I ask yours.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: She has not a shilling fortune.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I am glad of it, I have sufficient fortune for both,—I will settle a fortune on her.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: A fellow of noble generosity!—

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: There is a gentleman, I am determined she shall marry.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p:
Mark me,—let that gentleman be whom he may, if he presumes to speak to her, write to her,—or even thinks of her as a wife, I shall
make him such an example—but this is losing time,—farewell, I must wait on Constance.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: (Opposing him.) You shall not go an inch into my house,—that is your way out.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I will go into any man's house, Sir, where she is,—debar me access to my love!—Were you the Grand Signor, and detain'd her, I would force into the inmost recesses of your seraglio, put you to death in the midst of your Janissaries, and carry her off in triumph.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: I do not often swear, it is not my way, but damn me if I would not assist you.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Nay, then we must try your courage, (lays his hand upon his sword) —O, for an estringent to brace my nerves.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Excuse me from running you through the body while you wear my cloaths; that coat is in excellent taste, and I cannot think of running it through the body.—

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: A soldier, and a wit!

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Take it, take it; (throws off Welford's coat) —now let me see if you get into my house. (draws.)

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: What, going to sight a duel!—Oh, for shame!—duelling is a mode of satisfaction unworthy gentlemen, practis'd now by every vulgar fellow;—people of fashion should explode it.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: (Trembling.) You know I pay great respect to your opinion,—and if,—but he shall not go into my house.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Consider what an improper place for quarreling.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p:
You are right, Sir, this is too cold a situation for stripping;— (takes up the cloaths
and hands them to Ordeal.) now for Constance, love, and happiness. Exit Welford, running.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Bravo, my boy!—bravo!

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Sure some malign devil has determin'd to make me ridiculous!—let me after him. (Ordeal holds him.)

div3.stage: Enter Lady FLIPPANT, MUSLIN, and GRACE.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Are you mad, Sir Buzzard?

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Stark mad!

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Nearly stark naked mad.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: The cloaths,—the smuggled cloaths you provided for me.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Away! you old—get home;—perhaps your Scotch tutor may prepare Pure Nature for the grand tour, and provide you more company than you expect.—Why did I marry?—why plunge into a mortal disease, for which there is no remedy but poison,—no relief but death? Exit Sir Buzzard.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Can I see Constance?

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: She is lock'd up in her own apartment to avoid her lover.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: To avoid him!—He is a noble fellow, and she must have him;—I will in to Sir Buzzard, and argue this case:—He presumes to controul this young lady, his niece, by parental authority; but I will convince him, the principle of that authority is to make our children or wards happy,—not miserable.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Sir Buzzard is in a horrid rage.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p:
I must contrive to appease him. Constance I suppose has her suspicions;—an
amicable girl—I really love her, pity her situation, and am determined never to see Welford again, but for the purpose of facilitating a marriage between them.—I must also effectuate a breach between my sister and this pusilanimous colonel.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: That may be easily accomplished—the widow has no small share of vanity.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: True!—

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: We must persuade her she was the object of Mr. Welford's admiration.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: I will swear he brib'd me to introduce him to her.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: And I will contrive to get her and the gentleman together at my house, and your ladyship shall send the Colonel to surpirze them, which will produce an irreconcileable quarrel.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Here comes the widow—do you lay the train.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: De Courcy is gone, after a very loud altercation with Cheaterly, which terminated in mutual vows of vengeance; he charges Cheaterly with having imposed on him at play.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: There is nothing scandalous in that—play has become a science, fashionable in practice, and like other faux pas, 'tis only blameable in discovery. Pray how has Constance behaved?

sp.speaker: Wdi.
sp.p: Remains locked up in her own room▪ and perseveres in denying an interview to her lover:—this De Courcy is in my opinion a charming fellow.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: But I must know for what purpose he was brought into my closet.—I am certain Constance was not the object; so speak, Grace.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Well, my lady, the truth is, the gentleman came after the widow.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: I thought so,—this duplicity, sister, hurts me.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Dear, my lady, it is all my fault,—the gentleman saw Mrs. Volatile at the play with your ladyship, and sent for me in the morning—and,—but am I sure of pardon if I tell?

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Yes, if you tell nothing but the truth.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Well, my lady, the poor young gentleman to be fureswore bitterly he was smitten;—by all the Gods, says he, she is one of the most beautifulest,—most youngest, and most elegantest creatures my eyes ever beheld!—but I, telling him as how she was positively engaged to colonel Staff,—then he began to curse.—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Why presume to tell him so?—Who gave you knowledge of my engagements?

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
Grace.
sp.p: Do'nt be angry, madam,—I told him, madam—thinking no harm, and so he curs'd, and call'd on Heaven, and poor gentleman sigh'd so, that I took pity on him, and by his persuasions and promises brought him into the closet, where he was to have been concealed,—Yes, ma'am—'till I could have contriv'd to have brought you into the room, which I should have done, but that my lady first came, and then Sir Buzzard, who made up the noise that disturb'd the house.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: You are an impudent girl, go wait in my dressing-room 'till my coming.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p:
Yes, my lady,—but oh, sure, you do'nt intend to discharge me,—what could I do
when so pretty a gentleman knelt to me, and cried to me for assistance—and squeez'd my hand, and forc'd a purse into my bosom—Oh! oh! (crying, apart to the widow) —you will speak to my lady.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I will, Grace! (apart) there (gives money) —let me see you presently.
A pretty scheme this!—your maid, Lady Flippant, has used me well—did I ever make any positive engagements with the Colonel?

sp.speaker: La. Flip.
sp.p: I hope not, but really you take such pains to torment each other, I was apprehensive you were privately married.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Heav'n forbid!—I have been prudently considering the Colonel's situation some time past—his estate I understand has been long languishing in a decline, and his creditors no doubt are in expectation of mine.

sp.speaker: La. Flip.
sp.p: Then to bestow it on Welford—think of the pleasure of sweet five and twenty smiling upon you from morning 'till night.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: And from night to morning—think of that, madam.

sp.speaker: La. Flip.
sp.p: Then our triumph over a girl of such beauty as Constance—the buz of the polite world, and their impertinent ill-nature.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Certainly there are inducements.

sp.speaker: La. Flip.
sp.p:
Inducements! you will have the exquisite satisfaction of being lampoon'd, epigramm'd, and paragraph'd—or perhaps be etch'd in aqua fortis, and stuck up in the print shops. Then to have the tribe of antiquated maidens, disgusted wives, and disappointed widows railing at your prudence, yet envying
your situation—"Lord bless us!"—ejaculates Lady Toothless, "I wonder at her indiscretion, to marry a man so young. The Colonel would have been much more suitable."—Then she takes five years from your lover's age, and adds to your's—"That's he!—that's he!"—exclaims Miss Squintum, as she ogles from a side box, with one eye worn out in searching for defects in beauty, and the other on the decline—"That's he,—but I cannot perceive what she saw in the fellow; he is as plain as herself—and I wonder how women can follow fellows."—The blooming youth hands you to your seat—the whole circle stare at you—a general whisper's breath'd round—you gaze in return with perfect composure—salute your acquaintance—adjust your tucker, giggle behind your fan, assume a perfect indifference, whisper your handsome husband to mortify them, and laugh out to shew your inward satisfaction and ineffable contempt.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But how is all this to be brought about?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Call at my house within an hour, and if I do not settle it, discard me from your confidence.—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: She shall be punctual—come, sister, I see you were unacquainted with your lover's passion,—but you must acknowledge I had sufficient cause for suspicion.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Yet you must allow there was no deceit on my part. Exit Widow.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: You have play'd your part admirably.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Yes, Muslin, all good actresses are not upon the stage.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: You are no longer a Scotchman I zee—

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Yes, Nicholas, I have only laid aside the tone and accent, but am still a Scotchman; I have no reason to be ashamed of my country, and I trust my country will never have reason to be ashamed of me.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Why zee master, I could never zee any difference between your English and Scotch; though to be zure I could hear it in their speaking, and that is the only difference I think should ever be between them; but take a fool's advice now,—make the best use of your time.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: What employs your thoughts, my love?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: In truth, love itself; if the pleasing description you have given me be true, and I have no reason to doubt your veracity, to live with those we love must be the extent of human happiness;—but then, Mr. Ordeal has told me that your sex often requite the most sincere passion with cold indifference.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: The charge is too true; but my affection can only cease with life.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
I owe every thing to Mr. Ordeal's goodness, and the very arguments you urged to gain my love, persuade me against being ungrateful!—obedience is the only return I can make his kindness, and how can I disobey him, when my heart informs me that ingratitude is
one of those heinous sins at which Heaven is most offended?

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: It is true, no quality of the soul is more lovely than gratitude;—but Mr. Ordeal is not actuated by passion,—he offers you his hand from motives of generosity, not love,—all you owe him is friendship, which an union with me could not diminish.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: You can persuade me to any thing;—you swear you love me,—I believe you,—and if the pleasure I take in seeing you, and hearing you, and the pain I feel when you leave me, be love, I love you above all things.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Have you settled every thing?

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Good Nicholas, do not interrupt her.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Who, I, a spoil-sport! mum!—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Would not my consenting to marry you be injustice to my benefactor?

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: The value I set upon your love is such, I would not accept it, but as the voluntary gift of your soul!—I will obtain Mr. Ordeal's consent.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Then I am for ever yours. (He kisses her hand.)

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: (aside) —What do I see!

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: But when will you obtain his consent?

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: O, we are undone.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p:
(to Douglas) Is this the way you repay my confidence? and you, (to Clara) innocent
miss, is this a grateful return for years of kindness?—But (to Nicholas) what shall I say to you, rascal!—you, whom I thought watchful as a lynx, have slumber'd like another Argus—were your eyes piped into a nap by this Mercury, or was your mouth stopped by a sop, Mr. Cerberus?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Yes, I loves a sop;—but I will be called no names—zee master,—our bargain is this, a month's warning, or a month's wages; zo, pay me, and I'll go, but remember it was not I brought maister M'Classic into the house.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Your resentment, Sir, must fall solely upon me—I only have deceiv'd you,—a word in private,— (takes Ordeal aside) could human nature repel the influence of such beauty?— (points to Clara) had I been less honourable, or Clara less virtuous, I might now perhaps be imposing upon your credulity a seduced maid, with a vitiated mind: I am young,—Clara is pure nature,—the experiment I have made was dangerous.—

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: But you were only to have made the experiment to try how far her inclinations coincided with mine.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Consider, she was an orange tree.—

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: You were to have been the instrument for promoting my happiness.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: She possess'd the verdure of the spring—

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Hear me!

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: The blossom of the summer—

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Hear me!

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: The ripe fruit of autumn.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p:
And you would consider me the falling leaf in winter—hear me, Sir!— (loud) Have
you not been urging the temptations of pleasure to seduce her into your own designs?—have you not alienated her affections from me?

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Sir, I came into your house for the very purpose of gaining her love.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Who are you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: A soldier—my name Douglas,—my fortune a competency,—my country Scotland—the same person who assisted you when attack'd by ruffians on Marlborough Downs.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: The kind gentleman in whose arms I fainted!

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: From the first instant I saw her, my soul caught the inspiration of virtuous love.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: You are unfashionable, Sir,—from the dissipated conversation of the young fellows of the times, one would imagine there was neither honesty in man, nor chastity in woman;—but your conduct contradicts their aspersions.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: It is too true, the arts of seduction are so sedulously studied, that honest love appears in danger of being extirpated.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: There are many, many melancholy examples;—but be assured, young man, though sensual pleasures arise from seducing innocence, it is plucking blossoms from a sweet-briar, which will rankle in the flesh.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Your observation, Sir, is just,—though it does not apply to me.—

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: "My censure does not fall solely on youth,—no, the gardens of beauty and innocence are also despoil'd by old debilitated wretches, who cannot cultivate the soil, but lay waste its beauties."

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Do you forgive me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: I blame you not, I am your debtor for many instances of duty and affection;—look on her, Douglas;—yet her beauty is the least of her excellence,—but as it is a principal part of benevolence to assist another most when there is most need of assistance,—and that you need not owe too much to the generosity of your husband,—as you cannot be my wife, I adopt you for my child—love inspires its votaries with sentiment, and I acknowledge the benign influence. (Joins their hands.)

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: You weep, my lovely Clara!

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: And so do you,—and so do I,—I see you are all joy,—but, my children, the transports of a virtuous passion are the least parts of its happiness,—we will this instant to Sir Buzzard Savage's,—a young lady, his niece, calls for my protection.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: You mean Constance Heartfree! young De Courcy, of York, my particular friend, is, I believe, betrothed to her.—

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: You are right;—take your bride by the hand;—the women will laugh at me for losing her, but I am above the laugh of the world, and I will laugh at the world in my turn,—that is my way.— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: THE storm bends this way, and here will I meet it. (Sits down, and takes a book.)

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: (Pushing Grace before him) you shall instantly march out of my house. (Pushes her.)

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: My lady scorns your suspicions.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Stop your gabble, you diminitive pandar in petticoats!—It is clear that Constance was ignorant of Welford's arrival in England!—it is apparent he did not come to my house after her.—What, is your noble blood at a loss for an excuse?

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Who has instilled jealousy into that head of yours, barren of every thing but what is monstrous! (Reads.)

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: It is your Ladyship has made my head monstrous.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Sure the devil instigates some women!—the widow—

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Do not throw the blame on the poor devil—it is nature instigates them, and she is to the full as subtle and certain in her operations.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
I just now spoke to her as she stept out of a chair into Mrs. Muslin's, and in return was
shot through the heart with a look of ill-nature and contempt—if I was not the coolest fellow in the service, I'd run mad,—aye,—mad, mad—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: You would have cause to run mad, if you knew she is now at Mrs. Muslin's, enjoying a tete-a-tete with Welford.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Impossible!

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: I am ready to take my oath of it! (to Sir Buzzard) the truth is, I told a great lie to your honour.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: O, confound me, but I believe you now. Exit Grace.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: The widow gone to Welford, on an assignation—ha! ha! ha! I will after her this instant, and cut his throat!—No, I will not stir—I am pleas'd—perfectly pleas'd!—I will discharge such a volley about his ears;—gone to visit Welford!—but why should I be vex'd?—I will follow her, spring a mine, and blow them up together—Burst on her like a hand-granade.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Ridiculous—you are all gunpowder.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ungrateful woman!

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Deceitful sex!

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Surprize her and her lover!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I will break with her—I mean I will pursue her. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Well, you see it was your sister, not your wife, Welford came to visit; are you ready to make an apology for your vulgar suspicions?

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p:
An apology to you! O, impudence! have you not been the rust of my health, have you not fretted me down to a mere skeleton?
make you an apology!—give me my wasted flesh.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: I shall for London in the morning.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: If you dare!

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Will shew out at every place of public entertainment.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: At your peril.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: At your cost.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: The law gives me authority to confine you, and I will exercise it—I am your husband.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: I am heartily sorry for it! will have public breakfasts, public dinners, and public nights.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: You shall have bread and water, in a narrow room.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: A box at the Opera, and subscribe to all the Concerts.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: You devil!

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Will purchase a new vis-a-vis—a town chariot and phaeton.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: You—you have a design upon my life.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p:
Heav'ns! how ardently I pant to be elevated in the phaeton, to take the circuit of Hyde Park, rolling in a cloud of dust, four horses, two outriders, whip in hand, flowing manes, hunters tails, sweep down Piccadilly, turn into St. James's-street,—up fly the clubhouse windows, out pop the powdered heads of the bucks and beauxs of fashion—some nod, some smile, some kiss hands,—all praise—she is a goddess, exclaims one,—a venus, ejaculates another,—an angel, sighs a third. I cut on, flash
down Pall Mall swift as lightning, rattle furiously through Charing-Cross, overturn Lady Dapper's whim and cats at Northumberland House, lose a wheel in the Strand, leap from my seat as the carriage falls, and am received in the arms of some handsome fellow whom love has directed to my assistance.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: She is mad! she is mad! outrageous mad!

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: He carries me into a house, fainting—

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Stop there; I will be divorc'd.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Then I will have a separate maintenance.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Not a shilling.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: You cannot deprive me of my settlement.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Ay, there is the grievance! O, confound all jointures and settlements, those encourage your levities, and stimulate you all to transgress. Exit Sir Buzzard.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: (Sits.) My poor spirits are exhausted! Heigh ho! I am tired of this dissipated life.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I wait upon your ladyship, to return grateful thanks for the many favours you have conferred upon me, and to take my leave, as I am determined to quit this house.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: What! without your uncle's consent?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I cannot think his consent necessary, while he and your ladyship assent to the persecution I experienced from a man I despise.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: (Rising) And pray where do you intend to go?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I have found a protector—Mr. Ordeal, the friend of my unfortunate father. Lady Flippant, it hurts my heart to part you upon those terms. (Weeps and walks as going.)

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: In tears, Constance! (Constance returns) Why so distress'd?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: My heart is too full.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Be seated; (they sit) you love this Mr. Welford sincerely—but he is! (aside) what is it to me what he is! (Rises)

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: To me he is every thing—and it is my hope!— (rises) —but why should I hope?—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Constance—I really love you—our manners have divided us; but be assured, my dear girl, though I run the circle of fashionable life, my mind is not devoid of sensibility—our education has been different.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: It was my happiness to receive instruction from a pious and tender mother, who early taught me the precepts of virtue, and impressed upon my heart, that a pure reputation with humble poverty, was preferable to a suspicious character, though blazoned with all the pomp and ornaments of elevated life—but she is no more.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: (Rises) Alas, Constance! it was my misfortune to be educated in all the giddy foibles and levities of the times.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: (Rises) But I have observed a disposition in your ladyship susceptible of the tenderest offices of friendship,—and where there is feeling—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p:
There is hope of reformation—you would have said so—indeed, Constance,
there are sentiments here, which often upbraid me; but sure nothing has transpir'd, injurious to my honour.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: The world is censorious, madam, and those whose conversation is the most entertaining are often the most dangerous; to simplicity they impute cunning, and give a criminal construction to the most innocent actions.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: I am all joy, Lady Flippant! Constance, this is Clara, hereafter I trust you will be inseparable friends.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: I shall endeavour to merit the lady's friendship.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: They may boast of Queen Emma walking over burning ploughshares, but here is a girl has done more, she has lived in a fashionable family without censure. (Takes Constance by the hand.)

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: But, Mr. Ordeal, what is the cause of your joy?

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: It must be disclos'd—Pure Nature has bestowed her hand and heart on the Scotch lad, who turns out to be Captain Douglas, Welford's intimate friend.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Sir, I know the gentleman, and he bears a high character.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Constance, take this young lady to the drawing-room, send Grace to me, and order your maid over to Welford's, to let him know you will be there presently. I have a serious reason for my request, and will not be denied.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I obey. Exeunt Constance and Clara.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: The poor girl's situation is truly pitiable—it was our subject when you came in—the tears are not yet out of my eyes.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Never blush for weeping; tears are the certain symptoms of a noble soul.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Do you know that I have serious thoughts of throwing aside all fashionable levities?

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: I know it is almost time; I believe your inclinations are virtuous, and your irregularities I do not impute to nature;—no, my lady, nature has endowed you with amiable qualities, among which, I think generosity is prevalent—like most of your sex, you have taken up levity through whim, and maintain it through habit, though perhaps your soul struggles to be delivered from the trammels;—break them, then, and you will do more than Caesar;—he conquered countries,—but the greatest glory human nature can acquire is to conquer ourselves;—I have good news for Constance,—her father is living.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Heav'ns!—are you serious?

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: I have had letters from London, and he returns by the next ships from India;—nay more,—he has remitted thirty thousand pounds to her sole use, with directions to prepare a house for his reception.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: O, I am overjoy'd—why has she never heard from him before?

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: He was sent upon an embassy to the interior parts of the country, and his letters were intercepted and destroyed.—But seriously, has your ladyship known nothing of this before?

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: There is roguery on foot,—an express was sent to your seat at York, which not meeting the lady there was forwarded to this city, and delivered at this house.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
Ord.
sp.p: I hope so!—but I believe nothing without proof—that is my way—where there is levity the world will suspect, and when the world has once cause to suspect a woman, her character becomes as much the sport of its malice, as if there was a certainty of her having abandoned it.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: I am penitent! but do you really forgive my lecture to Pure Nature?

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Yes, and am convinc'd you are no false prophet; for, as you foretold, Clara preferred the summer dimples of youth to the winter wrinkles of age,—I speak my mind, that is my way.

div3.head: SCENE II. Mrs. Muslin's.
div3.stage: The WIDOW, Mrs. MUSLIN, and WELFORD, discovered at Tea.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p:
Your opinion, madam, is just! vivacity is an attribute to woman,—gravity natural
to man:—and probably the sexes were thus contrasted, that the saturnine disposition of the male might be relieved by the sprightliness of the female,—your smiles alleviate our pains, your approbation rewards our dangers.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And our conversation illustrates my opinion—you are grave,—I, perhaps, too volatile.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: The poor gentleman seems as if something preyed upon his mind;—let me recommend matrimony,—it is the only cure for melancholy.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: And often a specific for all complaints.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Well,—business must be minded (going.)

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: (Rises.) Must see you to the door.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: (Aside.) A great fortune,—may I trust her with you?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: May I trust myself with her? (aside.) Exit Mrs. Muslin. A good, merry, convenient, civil old woman:—she recommends matrimony— (sits.) Pray, madam, what kind of lover would you prefer?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I must tell you the lover I would not prefer. I would not prefer a coxcomb,—a fluttering summer insect,—a talkative creature, full of insipid gesture, laughter, and noise, who pays more attention to his hair than to his intellects,—who possesses neither sentiment for friendship, nor sensibility for love—but is curst with a soul devoid of manliness, and bent on the gratification of its own puny affections.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: An excellent picture, yet the species of animal you describe are favorites.—The ladies are grown so enamoured of delicate limbs, and effeminate faces, one would imagine they wished to have their lovers women in every thing.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Dear Sir, there is a woman below enquiring for you—she insists upon coming up, and has such a tongue!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I would not be seen for the world.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: She would surely blast the reputation of my house.—Sir, you must go down to her.—O my poor character! Exit Mrs. Muslin.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Any thing to save the reputation of your house. (Going.)

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Madam, madam, the slut is upon the stairs.—Step into this closet till the impudent creature is gone.— (Puts the widow in the closet) You do not know, Sir, you have been sitting with Mrs. Volatile, sister to Sir Buzzard Savage.

sp.speaker: Honor.
sp.p: (Within) Mr. Welford.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I know that voice.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: It is the clack of Mrs. Honor, waiting maid to Miss Constance.

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: Then keep her out for Heaven's sake.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: (Within) I will have admittance.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Coming, Mrs. Honor.—O the audacious wretch—I see, Sir, you are a man of gallantry, but, pray, dispatch the creature as fast as possible. Exit. Mus.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: (Within) Madam I insist upon going in first.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: (Within) No me'm—you will pardon me.

div3.stage: Enter GRACE and HONOR pushing in together.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: What, two!—ladies, your most obedient.— (bows—they curtsey)

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: You have no business here, me'm,—

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: My business, me'm, is no business of your's—or if it was your business, me'm, yet it is not the business of the likes of you to look down upon the likes of me, me'm.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: The likes of you I look down upon with scorn.—It is not for the likes of you, to look up to the likes of me, me'm.—I serves a lady of vartue.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Vartue! Your insinuation is low, me'm, high as you carry your head.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Grace, stand on my right hand—Honor, take your place on my left—How happy would it be for England, were all her great men in my situation—Grace supporting one side, Honor supporting the other.—Now, ladies, to the cause of your visit.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: My lady understanding that her sister was here— together.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: My Lady sent me to let you know— together.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: One at a time.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Sir, you must know— together.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: My lady sent— together.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Here is a guinea for her who speaks second—What; dumb!—but money seals as well as unseals the mouths of great speakers.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Me'm, I shall certainly speak first—Sir, you must know—

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Speak first, me'm! I serve a lady of quality.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Order in the house—let me settle this point of precedence—I believe it is regular that Grace should take the lead of Honor, so Mrs. Grace begin.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Thank you for preferring she.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Now Grace, what is your basiness with me?

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: La, Sir, I have no business with you—I want to speak with Mrs. Volatile.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Child, she is not here.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Not here—but I believe she is there

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: By this guinea she is not. (gives money.)

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: By this guinea I will swear it—mum—but my lady wants to see her directly—Mrs. Honor, your very obedient—an audacious hussey!— (aside.) Exit Grace.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Me'm, your most humble— (aside.) Lord, Sir, I found it as difficult to get at you, as if you had been a great Turk.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Mrs. Muslin did not know you perhaps.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Not know me! she knew me to be vartuous, though as the saying is, "tell me your company and I will tell you what you are"—and I, and my mistress live in a family where there is not much vartue practised—but I am silent—servants should neither have eyes, nor ears, nor tongues, therefore I am always blind, deaf and dumb, let me hear or see what I may.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Lower your voice, you may be overheard.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Then there is Sir Buzzard's sister, the widow, though her husband is not dead six months, is frisky and brisk—gadding about, and running mad for another—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Speak low, a gentleman lies ill in the next room.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p:
As to Sir Buzzard, they have put their
fingers into his eyes so often, he is blind as a beetle. I must make you laugh about the widow—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I cannot permit you to stay any longer from your Lady. Here's for your good report

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Dear Sir, you distress me—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Farewell— (pushing her out.) Exit Honor. Heav'n be prais'd! I have got rid of you!—Now to relieve my widow, who I suppose is mortified into humility, or bursting with rage.

Madam, I feel for your situation, and did every thing in my power to stop the impetuous flow of the woman's tongue—but be not affected at what she said—"Censure and calumny are taxes paid by the most elevated characters, nor is it possible to make defence against the impost, but by obscurity."

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: It is beneath me, Sir, to defend my character against the aspersions of so mean a wretch—I feel however for the impressions her falshoods may have made on you.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: You seem frightened, madam, quite fluster'd I protest—sure the gentleman attempted no rudeness—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: That woman has slandered me grosly!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Soothe your passion, madam, nothing so prejudicial to beauty as intemperate warmth—consider the vulgar set up a prescription, for exercising latitude of tongue, that shews no respect to persons.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Your hand, Mrs. Muslin—some drops—some water—I faint—I am overcome—I die! oh! (faints in Welford's arms.)

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Support her, dear Sir, 'till I return—let me run for restoratives— (going, returns) open her hands, chafe her temples,—a-lack a day—This is a master stroke of the widow's!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: This is worse than the state of Tantalus—human nature cannot hold out—she is really handsome. I will venture to kiss her however—

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Madam, Sir,—there is Miss Constance and Colonel Staff with her—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What will become of me? (Springing from the couch.)

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: What will become of me?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: In his private chamber, and just sprung from his arms!—Oh, hell and furies! but I will be cool,—we, Sir, will meet hereafter; this intrusion, madam, is, I see, as unseasonable as unexpected; I am sorry to have interrupted you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I am unconcerned at your suspicions, Colonel,—you will not be censorious, Miss Constance—my business here was to prevent that imprudent step which you are about to take.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: You have succeeded, madam (going).

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Will you hear me?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I am sorty, Sir, for the confusion I have caused—having gained my esteem without difficulty—you have resign'd it with the same ease—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: (To the Widow) This undeniable proof of your duplicity has reinstated my senses, and I will run the gauntlet no longer—you feel am calm—quite calm,—but I will have revenge;—you, Sir?—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Well, Sir!—it is my duty to clear this lady from suspicion, to which her situation lays her open, and in which I am innocently involved.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You may have an interest in justifying yourself, Sir, but I request not to be included in your defence; I am going.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I give up the pursuit—Madam, if my acts and deeds—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Your acts and deeds! Yes, I have heard of your acts and deeds from yourself, Colonel—but, be assured, a man without spirit shall never controul the acts and deeds of my fortune.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: A true Parthian,—she shot as she slew.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Constance, will you attend to me?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
No, Sir,—you need not take the trouble
of speaking to me now, or of enquiring for me hereafter. Exit. Constance.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Was ever man so unfortunate!—to have all my wishes blasted in the moment of ripening!—to lose the object of my love in the instant of recovering her—who waits there? to have an intrigue with a wife, a widow, and a maid, in the course of one day, and be disappointed in all—will nobody answer? (calling loud.)

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: What is the mater, Sir?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Where is the lady?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: She went out with the Colonel.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I speak of the young lady.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: She left the house in a chair,—but I cannot tell where she went.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I will this instant to Sir Buzzard's!—I will follow her over the world;—what an unfortunate fellow!— Exit. Welford.

div3.stage: SCENE changes to the Parade. Enter CHEATERLY, followed by a servant.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: What answer has Doctor Spruce sent?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: He said, Sir, he would not write,—but remember your ungenerous treatment, and have revenge!—pardon me, Sir, but these were his words.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Would have revenge?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p:
Yes, Sir, and I saw a letter on his table directed to Sir Buzzard Savage;—there was an
attorney with him, and I heard him say the penalty is treble the money lost.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: How much is he arrested for?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Upwards of seventy pounds.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Here is a note for a hundred— (gives a note) fly and get him discharged.
A letter to Sir Buzzard!—an attorney with him!—treble the penalty!—this Spruce I fear will turn traitor.
Captain Douglas, your most obedient,—how long have you been in Bath? I have not seen you for an age.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: I believe, Sir, not since the York meeting, when my friend De Courcy lost his money.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: He is too ardent to attempt play,—always off his guard.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: And had the misfortune to play with those who kept a constant centinel upon his weakness;—he confided in you, and was deceived;—care, and a plain understanding, may preserve a man's property from the plunder of a common robber,—but honesty has no protection from the frauds of superior cunning.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: I won nothing from him;—I lost—the truth is, the knowing ones took us in.—

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: But you shared the winnings—

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Will you dare—

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: I will dare any thing that is honest.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Your friend, Sir, has dared to traduce my character, by the imputation you insinuate. But he and you should know me better, than to suppose any man could affront me with impunity. (lays his hand on his sword.)

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: I know you have a mind capable of vindicating your conduct, even at the risque of your own life, and the life of him you have injured—men like you, habituated in deceit, become callous to humanity;—destitute of principle,—they are not deterred by the compunctions of conscience,—but will insure the profits of their cunning, even at the price of blood.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: My family, Sir—

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: Is honourable!—speak not of your family—their virtues render your vices the more conspicuous.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Oh you traitor!—the reverend Mr▪ Spruce has made a full confession.—So I have been your pigeon, but the law shall do me justice.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: This is your scheme, pusillanimous, mean wretch— (to Sir Buzzard) for you, Sir, (to Douglas) we shall meet again.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Yes,—at the next assizes;—the fellow's mind is sowed with hempseed, and will yet produce a halter.—or if he escapes hanging, I shall see him perishing in a gaol, under as many wants as are in the Daily Advertiser;—have you been pigeon'd, Sir?

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: No Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: I have,—he has pluck'd some quill feathers from me,—he has pinion'd me!—oh the rascal!—but I shall recover my mortgages, and bonds, with treble penalties!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Distraction!—she is lost!—I have been at your house, my Lady,—at Mr. Ordeal's—at every inn in the town,—but can get no tidings of her.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: It is surprising, you, who possess a heart open and liberal, panting with affection for the whole sex, should run distracted for the loss of an individual!

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.p: You overlook me, Welford—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Douglas!—my friend!—O, Douglas, I have lost my Constance!—I—

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: No truant, I have been your advocate and regained her for you—on condition of repentance—.

div3.stage: Enter CONSTANCE and CLARA followed by ORDEAL.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: My life!— (they embrace.)

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Repentance!—let him marry, and he will live and die in a state of repentance.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: What!—marry me, an orphan without a shilling?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Talk not of wealth,—were the riches of the world in your possession, by Heaven they would not add a grain to the estimation of your worth.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Generous and noble!

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: (to Ord.) How, Sir, can I repay your generosity?

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: The satisfaction which results from aiding virtue in distress, is the only interest a generous mind can wish to receive for its services;—because it is the only interest such a mind can enjoy.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: Return to my house;—there you shall be acquainted with a matter which nearly concerns your happiness.

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: Which I never expect to taste!

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Your happiness is in your own power, commence the practice of virtue, and you will be enamoured of its sweets,—try the experiment, and never fear success.

sp.speaker: Lady Flip.
sp.p: What say you to that, Sir Buzzard?

sp.speaker: Sir Buz.
sp.p: I say a man can never be too old to mend—I say I have been positive all my life, and I say if you follow the advice of your ancient and sapient friend, my endeavours to procure domestic happiness shall not be wanting—Ordeal, the laugh will be against us both.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Laugh at me as long as you please, but had I married Clara, the laugh would have been still stronger against me;—the Scot has done right, and the girl has done right,—the mutual inclination of two virtuous souls, cannot but render them more virtuous;—the inhabitants of countries united by nature and policy should take every opportunity of strengthening the connexion;—I see you all think as I do!—and here I hope we shall also meet approbation.

sp.l: OUR growing Levities too clearly show,
That all our troubles from refinement flow.
Two ages since we valu'd plain attire,
Blue-apron'd was the Dame, straight-hair'd the Squire;
They call'd not houshold bus'ness vulgar cares,
Nor deem'd it ungenteel to say their pray'rs:
But arts improv'd, new Levities arose,
And Ladies chang'd the fashion of their clothes;
Hoop'd petticoats in ev'ry town were seen:
The snug rotunda pleas'd the virgin Queen,
And beef for breakfast serv'd her Lady-train;
No wonder that her sailors baffled Spain.
Yet still we've chiefs with love of glory fir'd;
But so had Rome when liberty expired;
"We've statesmen too, who burn with patriots flame,
"But so had Greece, when Greece had lost her fame."
"We've admirals who plow the briny deep,
"Through azure skies and rolling clouds they sweep,
"Invade the Planets in an Air Balloon,
"And fright from her propriety the Moon"—
Bess was a man, when danger call'd her pow'rs,
She was a woman in her private hours—
Few Levities, few luxuries she knew;
No cherries then in February grew:
May-dukes in April on the bough hung green,
And girls wore hanging-sleeves till full eighteen.
Few mothers teach their daughters grace or sense▪
But tell them taste in dress is excellence:
Bid them the Levities of rank assume,
And flaunt with spreading bow, or nodding plume;
Strut in a riding-dress, to shew their shapes;
Or stalk in boots, and coats with tripple capes.
Affecting ease, but impudently free,
The matron leans upon her cicisbee;
While cara sposa snugly keeps his wench,
Defies his duns, and revels in the Bench.
"Why, this is vice, not folly?" I agree;
But still this vice proceeds from Levity.
Some souls there are which moral sense sublimes,
A few blest spirits in the worst of times;
One in whom birth and piety are join'd;
Of native worth, and truly royal mind;
Who with benignant hand her blessings pours;
Who knows no Levities, but feels for yours.

p.hi: Those lines which are not marked with inverted commas, were taken from an epilogue written by Mr. Norris, for the author of the comedy.
